not ever get enough firefighting today

I arrived in Afghanistan a week ago and
since then I've been out on an operation
with the farming 101st Airborne Division
I'm in zari district which is west of

part of Afghanistan is the the IEDs
threat the day that I arrived here there
had been already an a soldier who had

Americans had lost both his legs on a

it's hall field of marijuana plants that
created a canopy there's a lot of

we had complete concealment but there's
really no cover and tell event opens
from three sides with various weapons
including a heavy machine gun I think
that the first emotion that goes through
your head in that point you know which
way to go
but when you can't see more than five
feet in any direction that that's a
difficult question to answer I crawled
out of the sea open to the edge
to a small irrigation ditch where I then
was able to start to take some pictures
and then things started to calm down
when you see round impacting just a few
feet away from you you there's no words
that can describe that fear that goes to
your mind and the regret of putting
yourself in that situation
Kirk we've just heard Tyler's hiring
account of his embed with a unit that's

you tell us a little bit more about why
they're there well the district that
Tyler is in is one of several just west
and southwest of Kandahar City where the
Americans have decided to go in in
recent weeks as part of a fitful
offensive in and around Kandahar hoping
to bring in some government services and
to gain control of that very key part of
southern Afghanistan can you tell us
more about why Kandahar is so important
Kandahar is the Taliban heartland and
the Pashtun heartland and so it's
necessary for the Americans to make some
headway there in order to gain traction
in the overall war effort but it's
proving very difficult in the
neighboring district where Tyler is they
had an offensive recently and by the
time they got there most of the
civilians had fled and most of the
Taliban had also fled but they left an
area heavily booby-trapped with mines
and and other things and it just you
know shows how difficult it's going to
be for them to win popular support and
also to defeat an enemy that can just
melt away and now in New England
building a super insulated home energy
and environment reporter Tom Zeller has
the story
stephen landau cares a lot about
efficiency and the environment he drives
a hybrid and he's done what he can to
green his suburban Boston home solar
tubes LED lights our high efficiency oil
burner his kids even have to watch mr.
Landau's power meter he's always on my
back to turn my light off in my room
now the Landau's are taking on the big
green challenge they're building a new
home so well designed and insulated that
it doesn't even have a furnace in
Vermont
I remember reading a book about a
holding engineer in England who designed
and built a house which was only needed
by his tea kettle and the his buddies he
brought over to have a party I thought
that was really fascinating idea the
idea is to have a home that gathers and
holds the sons or even the residents
body heat it's called a passive house
buildings are major contributors to
greenhouse gases linked to global
warming but in a passive house no
furnace means low emissions passive
houses are becoming more common in
Europe but the Landau's is one of only a
few in the United States their new home
built to tight tolerances in a factory
has walls three times thicker than a
conventional home and it costs about
$50,000 more to build it's more
insulation there's a little more in the
layers so there's a little more labour
also the windows are to a higher
standard so you're gonna spend more in
the windows but for the Landau's
building this green is less about cost
and more about philosophy everybody
should do it get on board
we should be spending our money on
